Explanations about Options.--adjust-system-clock(M):
If set-local-rtc is invoked and this option is passed, the system clock is
 synchronized from the RTC again, taking the new setting into account. Otherwise, the
 RTC is synchronized from the system clock.

Answers.MP Summary: Control the system time and date
Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Check the current system clock time

Explanations about Options.--systohc(M):
Set the Hardware Clock from the System Clock, and update the timestamps in
 /etc/adjtime. With the --update-drift option also (re)calculate the drift factor.
 Try it without the option if --systohc fails. See --update-drift below.
Explanations about Options.-w(M):
Set the Hardware Clock from the System Clock, and update the timestamps in
 /etc/adjtime. With the --update-drift option also (re)calculate the drift factor.
 Try it without the option if --systohc fails. See --update-drift below.

Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Write the current software clock time to the hardware clock (sometimes used during system setup)
Top-3 Scripts:
ul_205229: root@debian:/home/mohsen# date -s "Sat May 23 18:56:59 IRDT 2015"
root@debian:/home/mohsen# hwclock -w

hwclock -w

Answers.MP Summary: delay for a specified amount of time
Top-3 Scripts:
ul_314365: start_time="$(date -u +%s)"
sleep 5
end_time="$(date -u +%s)"

elapsed="$(($end_time-$start_time))"
echo "Total of $elapsed seconds elapsed for process"

 Total of 5 seconds elapsed for process

start_time="$(date -u +%s.%N)"
sleep 5
end_time="$(date -u +%s.%N)"

elapsed="$(bc <<<"$end_time-$start_time")"
echo "Total of $elapsed seconds elapsed for process"

 Total of 5.001884264 seconds elapsed for process
